elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new 2D Dysprosium compound [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid) has been successfully constructed by the hydrothermal reaction of Dy(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> with 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc, and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analysis, as well as single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The results reveal that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a 2-D framework with 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology constructed from one-dimensional lanthanide-3,4-qldc zigzag chains and oxalate pillars. To the best of our knowledge, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents the first example of the coordination compound containing 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc as the multi-functional ligand. Moreover, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a certain photoluminescent property and high thermal stability.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new 2D Dysprosium compound [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)0.5(H2O)2] n  (1) (3,4-H2qldc=3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid) has been successfully constructed by the hydrothermal reaction of Dy(NO3)3 with 3,4-H2qldc, and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analysis, as well as single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The results reveal that complex 1 possesses a 2-D framework with 44 topology constructed from one-dimensional lanthanide-3,4-qldc zigzag chains and oxalate pillars. To the best of our knowledge, complex 1 represents the first example of the coordination compound containing 3,4-H2qldc as the multi-functional ligand. Moreover, compound 1 displays a certain photoluminescent property and high thermal stability.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">A 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional oxo-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy2(3,4-qldc)2(H2O)4]n and ox2- pillars based on 3,4-H2qldc was successfully constructed under hydrothermal condition, in which complex 1 represents the first example of the coordination compound containing 3,4-H2qldc as the multi-functional ligand.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional oxo-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy2(3,4-qldc)2(H2O)4]n and ox2- pillars based on 3,4-H2qldc was successfully constructed under hydrothermal condition, in which complex 1 represents the first example of the coordination compound containing 3,4-H2qldc as the multi-functional ligand.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">► [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> is the first Ln<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> compound containing 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc. ► The compound is 2-D layer with 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology. ► The compound is constructed from 1-D Ln-3,4-qldc zigzag chains and ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> pillars.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)0.5(H2O)2]n is the first LnIII compound containing 3,4-H2qldc. ► The compound is 2-D layer with 44 topology. ► The compound is constructed from 1-D Ln-3,4-qldc zigzag chains and ox2- pillars.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a well-growing subject during the last two decades, not only because of the enormous variety of interesting molecular topologies, which are often unprecedented in inorganic compounds and minerals , but also due to their excellent properties with promising applications such as in gas storage, gas/vapor separation, size-, shape-, and enantio-selective catalysis, fluorescence and drug storage and delivery . In contrast to the fruitful production of MOFs with d-block transition-metal ions, the design and control of high-dimensional lanthanide-based frameworks is currently a challenge task owing to their high coordination numbers and flexible coordination environments . Due to high oxo-affinity of lanthanide ions, many dicarboxylate ligands such as pyridine-dicarboxylic acids have been widely employed previously to synthesize a number of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) with fascinating architecture . As the derivative of well studied pyridine-dicarboxylic acids, the coordination chemistry of 3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid has not been explored yet until now. In contrast, 3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid is chosen as multi-functional ligand, mainly according to the following considerations: (i) as an aromatic rigid ligand, 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc having large steric resistance is inclined to chelate Ln metal center to form low compounds such as 0-D and 1-D structures; (ii) the relatively large π-conjugated system in the quinoline ring might not only contribute much to the desirable fluorescence properties resulting from the interaction between 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions and metal ions, but also easily assemble into 3-D supramolecular network via π⋅⋅⋅π packing interactions between two adjacent aromatic rings ; (iii) to the best of our knowledge, the coordination chemistry of quinoline-3,4-dicarboxylic acid have been involved yet so far. Therefore, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reported here should be the first example of coordination compound containing 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a well-growing subject during the last two decades, not only because of the enormous variety of interesting molecular topologies, which are often unprecedented in inorganic compounds and minerals , but also due to their excellent properties with promising applications such as in gas storage, gas/vapor separation, size-, shape-, and enantio-selective catalysis, fluorescence and drug storage and delivery . In contrast to the fruitful production of MOFs with d-block transition-metal ions, the design and control of high-dimensional lanthanide-based frameworks is currently a challenge task owing to their high coordination numbers and flexible coordination environments . Due to high oxo-affinity of lanthanide ions, many dicarboxylate ligands such as pyridine-dicarboxylic acids have been widely employed previously to synthesize a number of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) with fascinating architecture . As the derivative of well studied pyridine-dicarboxylic acids, the coordination chemistry of 3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid has not been explored yet until now. In contrast, 3,4-Quinolinedicarboxylic acid is chosen as multi-functional ligand, mainly according to the following considerations: (i) as an aromatic rigid ligand, 3,4-H2qldc having large steric resistance is inclined to chelate Ln metal center to form low compounds such as 0-D and 1-D structures; (ii) the relatively large π-conjugated system in the quinoline ring might not only contribute much to the desirable fluorescence properties resulting from the interaction between 3,4-qldc2- anions and metal ions, but also easily assemble into 3-D supramolecular network via π⋅⋅⋅π packing interactions between two adjacent aromatic rings ; (iii) to the best of our knowledge, the coordination chemistry of quinoline-3,4-dicarboxylic acid have been involved yet so far. Therefore, the complex 1 reported here should be the first example of coordination compound containing 3,4-H2qldc.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was hydrothermally synthesized with a mixture of dysprosium nitrate, 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc, oxalic acid and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . The molecular formula of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was determined by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray analysis. In IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Figure <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>), the strong and broad absorption bands in the range 3250–3510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> are characteristic of the O–H vibration of water molecules. The spectrum also shows characteristic bands of carboxylate groups around 1550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> assignable to the asymmetric stretch and around 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> associated with the symmetric stretch . The difference of 253<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> between <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates that bridging carboxylates are in the <ce:italic>exo</ce:italic>-bidentate mode, as proven by the X-ray crystal structure analysis. The absence of strong bands ranging from 1690 to 1730<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> indicates that the ligands are deprotonated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was hydrothermally synthesized with a mixture of dysprosium nitrate, 3,4-H2qldc, oxalic acid and 20mL water sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 110°C for 72h . The molecular formula of compound 1 was determined by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray analysis. In IR spectrum of 1 (Figure S1), the strong and broad absorption bands in the range 3250-3510cm-1 are characteristic of the O-H vibration of water molecules. The spectrum also shows characteristic bands of carboxylate groups around 1550cm-1 assignable to the asymmetric stretch and around 1384cm-1 associated with the symmetric stretch . The difference of 253cm-1 between ν as(COO-) and ν s(COO-) in 1 indicates that bridging carboxylates are in the exo-bidentate mode, as proven by the X-ray crystal structure analysis. The absence of strong bands ranging from 1690 to 1730cm-1 indicates that the ligands are deprotonated.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>‾1 and features a 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional <ce:italic>oxo</ce:italic>-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3,4-qldc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> and ox<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> pillars. Its asymmetrical unit is composed of one dysprosium ion, one independent 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one-half oxalate ligand and two coordinated water molecules. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, each Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is nine-coordinated in a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry with five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3a, O3b and O4b) from three 3,4-qldc ligands, two oxygen atom (O5, O6) from one oxalate ligand and two oxygen atom (O7, O8) from two coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Dy―O bond distances range from 2.346(7) to 2.708(6) Å. The bond angles of O―Dy―O are in the range of 50.1(2)-155.2(6)° comparable to those in other Ln carboxylate complexes observed in our previous papers . In present case, the 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc was completely deprotonated and each 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligand via <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> coordination manner links two Dy(III) centers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>) to generate a 14-membered ring. On the basis of the coordination mode <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and conformation of ligand 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>, two neighboring rings are connected in parrallel into a 1-D zigzag chain along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis via two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O3 bridges (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). And then by means of the coordination mode <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-O of ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand (viewing as pillars), these one-dimensional chains are constructed to form two-dimensional layers as depicted in b. In order to identify the connectivity in the ligands and metals, the topology of the whole framework is investigated. While considering the dinuclear motif [Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] constructed by two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O3 from two 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands of two adjacent 14-membered rings as a node (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>), the C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (b) and 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (c) as linkers, the simplified topological representation of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is described in , which exhibits a 4-connected 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology (d). Moreover, through interlayer π...π stacking interactions, a 3-D network is assembled as shown in Figure <ce:bold>S2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P‾1 and features a 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional oxo-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy2(3,4-qldc)2(H2O)4]n and ox2- pillars. Its asymmetrical unit is composed of one dysprosium ion, one independent 3,4-qldc2- ligand, one-half oxalate ligand and two coordinated water molecules. As shown in  , each Dy3+ ion is nine-coordinated in a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry with five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3a, O3b and O4b) from three 3,4-qldc ligands, two oxygen atom (O5, O6) from one oxalate ligand and two oxygen atom (O7, O8) from two coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Dy-O bond distances range from 2.346(7) to 2.708(6) Å. The bond angles of O-Dy-O are in the range of 50.1(2)-155.2(6)° comparable to those in other Ln carboxylate complexes observed in our previous papers . In present case, the 3,4-H2qldc was completely deprotonated and each 3,4-qldc2- ligand via μ 3-η 1:η 1:η 1:η 2 coordination manner links two Dy(III) centers ( ) to generate a 14-membered ring. On the basis of the coordination mode I and conformation of ligand 3,4-qldc2-, two neighboring rings are connected in parrallel into a 1-D zigzag chain along a axis via two μ 2-O3 bridges (a). And then by means of the coordination mode μ 2-κ 4-O of ox2- ligand (viewing as pillars), these one-dimensional chains are constructed to form two-dimensional layers as depicted in b. In order to identify the connectivity in the ligands and metals, the topology of the whole framework is investigated. While considering the dinuclear motif [Dy2(μ 2-O)2] constructed by two μ 2-O3 from two 3,4-qldc2- ligands of two adjacent 14-membered rings as a node (a), the C2O4 2- (b) and 3,4-qldc2- (c) as linkers, the simplified topological representation of the compound 1 is described in , which exhibits a 4-connected 44 topology (d). Moreover, through interlayer π...π stacking interactions, a 3-D network is assembled as shown in Figure S2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The XPRD pattern of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that the title compound is pure single phase and is also of completely identical molecular structures, corresponding to the simulated results from the single-crystal X-ray data (Figure <ce:bold>S3</ce:bold>). The thermal stability of the title compound was examined and its TGA curve was shown in Figure <ce:bold>S4</ce:bold>. The experiment was performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of the compound under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. The crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showed the first endothermic weight loss of 7.97% around 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.87%) from one formula unit. And then the weight loss of 8.94% (calc. 9.5%) between 254 and 355<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C ascribes to the loss of half oxalate ligand from one formula unit, and the residue weight corresponds to Dy(3,4-qldc). Another major weight loss occurred in the range of 350–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was assumed to be the residual product in 40.91%, supported by the expected value of 40.71%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The XPRD pattern of compound 1 reveals that the title compound is pure single phase and is also of completely identical molecular structures, corresponding to the simulated results from the single-crystal X-ray data (Figure S3). The thermal stability of the title compound was examined and its TGA curve was shown in Figure S4. The experiment was performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of the compound under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The crystals of 1 showed the first endothermic weight loss of 7.97% around 260°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.87%) from one formula unit. And then the weight loss of 8.94% (calc. 9.5%) between 254 and 355°C ascribes to the loss of half oxalate ligand from one formula unit, and the residue weight corresponds to Dy(3,4-qldc). Another major weight loss occurred in the range of 350-800°C, Dy2O3 was assumed to be the residual product in 40.91%, supported by the expected value of 40.71%.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The solid-state luminescence property of this compound was investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Figure <ce:bold>S5</ce:bold>), obtained with excitation wavelength of 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, are composed of emission lines typical for Dysprosium (III). The emission at 479, 577, and 658<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is attributed to the characteristic emission of <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf>, and <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transitions of the Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. The relative intensity ratio for the emission lines at 479 and 573<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is indicative of the larger probability for the <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transition of the Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid-state luminescence property of this compound was investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of the compound 1 (Figure S5), obtained with excitation wavelength of 365nm, are composed of emission lines typical for Dysprosium (III). The emission at 479, 577, and 658nm is attributed to the characteristic emission of 4F9/2, and 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transitions of the Dy3+ ion. The relative intensity ratio for the emission lines at 479 and 573nm is indicative of the larger probability for the 4F9/2 → 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transition of the Dy3+ ion.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In summary, a new organic framework based on 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc was successfully constructed under hydrothermal condition for the first time. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a 2-D layer-like structure with 1D zigzag chains built up by dual-core Dy center and two 3,4-qldc ligands and oxalate dianion as pillars. Furthermore, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays the high thermal stability and the strong photoluminescent property.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new organic framework based on 3,4-H2qldc was successfully constructed under hydrothermal condition for the first time. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 features a 2-D layer-like structure with 1D zigzag chains built up by dual-core Dy center and two 3,4-qldc ligands and oxalate dianion as pillars. Furthermore, compound 1 displays the high thermal stability and the strong photoluminescent property.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Synthesis of [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (1). A mixture of 3,4-quinolinedicarboxylic (0.043<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g; 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), oxalic acid (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Dy(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g; 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was heated to 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and was then cooled to room temperature at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to obtain yellow block single crystals of 1 (yield: 75% based on Dy) Anal. Calcd for DyC<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (%): C, 31.46; H, 1.97; N,3.06. Found: C, 30.27; H, 2.04; N,3.21. IR frequencies (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3350, 1542, 1389, 1243, 1094, 964, 890,849, 792, 664, 618, 537.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)0.5(H2O)2]n (1). A mixture of 3,4-quinolinedicarboxylic (0.043g; 0.2mmol), oxalic acid (0.2mmol), Dy(NO3)3 (0.069g; 0.2mmol), and H2O (20mL) was heated to 110°C for 80h in a 25mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and was then cooled to room temperature at 10°C/h-1 to obtain yellow block single crystals of 1 (yield: 75% based on Dy) Anal. Calcd for DyC12 H9 N O8 (%): C, 31.46; H, 1.97; N,3.06. Found: C, 30.27; H, 2.04; N,3.21. IR frequencies (KBr, cm-1): 3350, 1542, 1389, 1243, 1094, 964, 890,849, 792, 664, 618, 537.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was hydrothermally synthesized with a mixture of dysprosium nitrate, 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc, oxalic acid and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . The molecular formula of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was determined by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray analysis. In IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Figure <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>), the strong and broad absorption bands in the range 3250–3510<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> are characteristic of the O–H vibration of water molecules. The spectrum also shows characteristic bands of carboxylate groups around 1550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> assignable to the asymmetric stretch and around 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> associated with the symmetric stretch . The difference of 253<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> between <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates that bridging carboxylates are in the <ce:italic>exo</ce:italic>-bidentate mode, as proven by the X-ray crystal structure analysis. The absence of strong bands ranging from 1690 to 1730<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> indicates that the ligands are deprotonated.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Synthesis of [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (1). A mixture of 3,4-quinolinedicarboxylic (0.043<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g; 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), oxalic acid (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Dy(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g; 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was heated to 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and was then cooled to room temperature at 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> to obtain yellow block single crystals of 1 (yield: 75% based on Dy) Anal. Calcd for DyC<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (%): C, 31.46; H, 1.97; N,3.06. Found: C, 30.27; H, 2.04; N,3.21. IR frequencies (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3350, 1542, 1389, 1243, 1094, 964, 890,849, 792, 664, 618, 537.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Compound 1 was hydrothermally synthesized with a mixture of dysprosium nitrate, 3,4-H2qldc, oxalic acid and 20mL water sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 110°C for 72h . The molecular formula of compound 1 was determined by elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray analysis. In IR spectrum of 1 (Figure S1), the strong and broad absorption bands in the range 3250-3510cm-1 are characteristic of the O-H vibration of water molecules. The spectrum also shows characteristic bands of carboxylate groups around 1550cm-1 assignable to the asymmetric stretch and around 1384cm-1 associated with the symmetric stretch . The difference of 253cm-1 between ν as(COO-) and ν s(COO-) in 1 indicates that bridging carboxylates are in the exo-bidentate mode, as proven by the X-ray crystal structure analysis. The absence of strong bands ranging from 1690 to 1730cm-1 indicates that the ligands are deprotonated.

Synthesis of [Dy(3,4-qldc)(ox)0.5(H2O)2]n (1). A mixture of 3,4-quinolinedicarboxylic (0.043g; 0.2mmol), oxalic acid (0.2mmol), Dy(NO3)3 (0.069g; 0.2mmol), and H2O (20mL) was heated to 110°C for 80h in a 25mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and was then cooled to room temperature at 10°C/h-1 to obtain yellow block single crystals of 1 (yield: 75% based on Dy) Anal. Calcd for DyC12 H9 N O8 (%): C, 31.46; H, 1.97; N,3.06. Found: C, 30.27; H, 2.04; N,3.21. IR frequencies (KBr, cm-1): 3350, 1542, 1389, 1243, 1094, 964, 890,849, 792, 664, 618, 537.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>‾1 and features a 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional <ce:italic>oxo</ce:italic>-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3,4-qldc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> and ox<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> pillars. Its asymmetrical unit is composed of one dysprosium ion, one independent 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one-half oxalate ligand and two coordinated water molecules. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, each Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is nine-coordinated in a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry with five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3a, O3b and O4b) from three 3,4-qldc ligands, two oxygen atom (O5, O6) from one oxalate ligand and two oxygen atom (O7, O8) from two coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Dy―O bond distances range from 2.346(7) to 2.708(6) Å. The bond angles of O―Dy―O are in the range of 50.1(2)-155.2(6)° comparable to those in other Ln carboxylate complexes observed in our previous papers . In present case, the 3,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>qldc was completely deprotonated and each 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligand via <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> coordination manner links two Dy(III) centers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>) to generate a 14-membered ring. On the basis of the coordination mode <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and conformation of ligand 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>, two neighboring rings are connected in parrallel into a 1-D zigzag chain along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis via two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O3 bridges (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). And then by means of the coordination mode <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-O of ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand (viewing as pillars), these one-dimensional chains are constructed to form two-dimensional layers as depicted in b. In order to identify the connectivity in the ligands and metals, the topology of the whole framework is investigated. While considering the dinuclear motif [Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] constructed by two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O3 from two 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ligands of two adjacent 14-membered rings as a node (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>), the C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (b) and 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (c) as linkers, the simplified topological representation of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is described in , which exhibits a 4-connected 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology (d). Moreover, through interlayer π...π stacking interactions, a 3-D network is assembled as shown in Figure <ce:bold>S2</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The XPRD pattern of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals that the title compound is pure single phase and is also of completely identical molecular structures, corresponding to the simulated results from the single-crystal X-ray data (Figure <ce:bold>S3</ce:bold>). The thermal stability of the title compound was examined and its TGA curve was shown in Figure <ce:bold>S4</ce:bold>. The experiment was performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of the compound under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. The crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showed the first endothermic weight loss of 7.97% around 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.87%) from one formula unit. And then the weight loss of 8.94% (calc. 9.5%) between 254 and 355<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C ascribes to the loss of half oxalate ligand from one formula unit, and the residue weight corresponds to Dy(3,4-qldc). Another major weight loss occurred in the range of 350–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, Dy<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was assumed to be the residual product in 40.91%, supported by the expected value of 40.71%.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The solid-state luminescence property of this compound was investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Figure <ce:bold>S5</ce:bold>), obtained with excitation wavelength of 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, are composed of emission lines typical for Dysprosium (III). The emission at 479, 577, and 658<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is attributed to the characteristic emission of <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf>, and <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transitions of the Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. The relative intensity ratio for the emission lines at 479 and 573<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm is indicative of the larger probability for the <ce:sup loc="pre">4</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">9/2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>
<ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transition of the Dy<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P‾1 and features a 2-D pillared-chained coordination framework constructed from one-dimensional oxo-bridged lanthanide chains [Dy2(3,4-qldc)2(H2O)4]n and ox2- pillars. Its asymmetrical unit is composed of one dysprosium ion, one independent 3,4-qldc2- ligand, one-half oxalate ligand and two coordinated water molecules. As shown in  , each Dy3+ ion is nine-coordinated in a distorted tricapped trigonal prismatic geometry with five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3a, O3b and O4b) from three 3,4-qldc ligands, two oxygen atom (O5, O6) from one oxalate ligand and two oxygen atom (O7, O8) from two coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Dy-O bond distances range from 2.346(7) to 2.708(6) Å. The bond angles of O-Dy-O are in the range of 50.1(2)-155.2(6)° comparable to those in other Ln carboxylate complexes observed in our previous papers . In present case, the 3,4-H2qldc was completely deprotonated and each 3,4-qldc2- ligand via μ 3-η 1:η 1:η 1:η 2 coordination manner links two Dy(III) centers ( ) to generate a 14-membered ring. On the basis of the coordination mode I and conformation of ligand 3,4-qldc2-, two neighboring rings are connected in parrallel into a 1-D zigzag chain along a axis via two μ 2-O3 bridges (a). And then by means of the coordination mode μ 2-κ 4-O of ox2- ligand (viewing as pillars), these one-dimensional chains are constructed to form two-dimensional layers as depicted in b. In order to identify the connectivity in the ligands and metals, the topology of the whole framework is investigated. While considering the dinuclear motif [Dy2(μ 2-O)2] constructed by two μ 2-O3 from two 3,4-qldc2- ligands of two adjacent 14-membered rings as a node (a), the C2O4 2- (b) and 3,4-qldc2- (c) as linkers, the simplified topological representation of the compound 1 is described in , which exhibits a 4-connected 44 topology (d). Moreover, through interlayer π...π stacking interactions, a 3-D network is assembled as shown in Figure S2.

The XPRD pattern of compound 1 reveals that the title compound is pure single phase and is also of completely identical molecular structures, corresponding to the simulated results from the single-crystal X-ray data (Figure S3). The thermal stability of the title compound was examined and its TGA curve was shown in Figure S4. The experiment was performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of the compound under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The crystals of 1 showed the first endothermic weight loss of 7.97% around 260°C, corresponding to the removal of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.87%) from one formula unit. And then the weight loss of 8.94% (calc. 9.5%) between 254 and 355°C ascribes to the loss of half oxalate ligand from one formula unit, and the residue weight corresponds to Dy(3,4-qldc). Another major weight loss occurred in the range of 350-800°C, Dy2O3 was assumed to be the residual product in 40.91%, supported by the expected value of 40.71%.

The solid-state luminescence property of this compound was investigated at room temperature. The emission spectra of the compound 1 (Figure S5), obtained with excitation wavelength of 365nm, are composed of emission lines typical for Dysprosium (III). The emission at 479, 577, and 658nm is attributed to the characteristic emission of 4F9/2, and 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transitions of the Dy3+ ion. The relative intensity ratio for the emission lines at 479 and 573nm is indicative of the larger probability for the 4F9/2 → 6HJ (J =15/2, 13/2 and 11/2) transition of the Dy3+ ion.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of two coordinated water molecules

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">(a) The defined nodes of 4-connected [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]motif in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (b) The defined linkers of 2-connected C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (c) The defined linkers of 2-connected 3,4-qldc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (d) The 2-D net of 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology in its most symmetrical form distinguished by different colors.</ce:simple-para>
